snippet: To the Sports Editor: How can William D. Warner (Mailbox, May 15) dare to say he holds professional sports ''very dear'' when he means he holds men's sports very dear? The idea that someone with such limited, one-sided vision still exists more tha...
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor: How can William D. Warner (Mailbox, May 15) dare to say he holds professional sports ''very dear'' when he means he holds men's sports very dear? The idea that someone with such limited, one-sided vision still exists more than 10 years after the inception of the women's movement amazes and depresses me. When the late Jack Dolph, a relative of mine, was commissioner of the American Basketball Association, I had the opportunity to attend several games.

headline.main: Female Sports Are Not Inferior

lead_paragraph: Patti Cooksey, a regular rider on the thoroughbred circuit in Ohio and Kentucky, won more races and more money than any female jockey in 1981, according to Daily Racing Form statistics. Miss Cooksey, 23, finished the year with 197 victories and more than $850,000 in purses earned by her mounts.

lead_paragraph: LEAD: Judith Davidson has been named athletic director at Central Connecticut State University, becoming only the second full-time female athletic director in Division I. The other is Eileen Livingston of Duquesne. Davidson, 43 years old, was the head field hockey coach at Iowa, where she was named Big Ten Coach of the Year three times and led her team to the national championship in 1986.

snippet: MY wife is mourning Diana. I am mourning Richie Ashburn. I am thinking of writing a book about the difference between women and men. The tentative title is, ''Women Are From London; Men Are From Philadelphia.''     Don't get me wrong. I feel terri...
lead_paragraph: MY wife is mourning Diana. I am mourning Richie Ashburn. I am thinking of writing a book about the difference between women and men. The tentative title is, ''Women Are From London; Men Are From Philadelphia.'' Don't get me wrong. I feel terrible about the senseless death of a vibrant young mother, I respect her altruistic impulses, and I'm sorry she died on the run from her dysfunctional in-laws and the hellhounds from the tabloids, but I feel no psychic connection to Diana because, generally speaking, guys do not grow up relating to princesses.

snippet: THE Cyndi Lauper song "Girls Just Want to Have Fun" is becoming a marketing mantra for a leading media company and a large advertiser as they play up sales  efforts aimed at young female athletes.         Sports Illustrated for Kids, published by ...
lead_paragraph: THE Cyndi Lauper song "Girls Just Want to Have Fun" is becoming a marketing mantra for a leading media company and a large advertiser as they play up sales efforts aimed at young female athletes. Sports Illustrated for Kids, published by Time Inc. under the aegis of Sports Illustrated magazine, will introduce a 16-page editorial section, Girls and Sports Extra, aimed at readers ages 8 to 14. Nike Inc. has agreed to be the sole sponsor of the first two sections. After they run -- probably in the October and December issues of Sports Illustrated for Kids -- the section is to appear six times a year beginning in 1997.

headline.main: Sports Illustrated and Nike hope girls just want to read about women's sports and female athletes.

Shepard is from Massachusetts; Dragila and her husband live in California. Shepard is a national high school champion making her first foray into prime time; Dragila is the 1997 world indoor champion.

snippet: THE lightning struck first in 1996, when the United States women's soccer team won the gold at the summer Olympic Games, a traditional generator of sports heroes. Then it happened again, a year ago. After a month of matches, the United States wome...
lead_paragraph: THE lightning struck first in 1996, when the United States women's soccer team won the gold at the summer Olympic Games, a traditional generator of sports heroes. Then it happened again, a year ago. After a month of matches, the United States women's soccer team -- composed largely of Olympic athletes -- beat China in a spectacular finale and captured the 1999 Women's World Cup. Before, during and after, the nation watched, rapt, as it rarely had for any women's team sport. Players like Mia Hamm became media darlings, their names known to all. And Madison Avenue sat up and paid attention. Or did it?
abstract: Among women athletes, sex appeal trumps athletic prowess in winning product endorsement contracts, and few achieve success in advertising on par with men (M)

snippet: THAT could be us. The message was not lost on the Americans. It was the summer of 1996 and they were all watching the Summer Games from Atlanta, wave upon wave of female athletes with muscles and nerve and skill.    Softball players. Basketball pl...
lead_paragraph: THAT could be us. The message was not lost on the Americans. It was the summer of 1996 and they were all watching the Summer Games from Atlanta, wave upon wave of female athletes with muscles and nerve and skill. Softball players. Basketball players. Field hockey players. Track and field athletes. Swimmers. Soccer players. Even the gymnasts with their squeaky voices and their little-girl personas were the real thing, jocks with gall like Kerri Strug, who took another turn on her wrenched ankle with the whole word watching.

snippet: FRANKENBERG--Babette Meyers Known to her family and many friends as "Bobbe," died February 28 at age 98, having lived a richly variegated and adventurous life that channeled her pioneering spirit as a feminist before her time. Bobbe was born on Ma...
lead_paragraph: FRANKENBERG--Babette Meyers Known to her family and many friends as "Bobbe," died February 28 at age 98, having lived a richly variegated and adventurous life that channeled her pioneering spirit as a feminist before her time. Bobbe was born on May 16, 1916, in the hardscrabble mining town of Bisbee, AZ, and moved with her parents to Beverly Hills when Sunset Boulevard had yet to be fully paved. She was a successful business woman in the 1940s, when female entrepreneurs were a rare breed, and through the 1980s, as women increasingly rose to prominence in corporate America. She found great success in commercial and residential real estate as well in public relations. In the 1950s she handled Mark Taper's PR for his ambitious Lakewood development. With Coldwell Banker, Bobbe sold many of the more remarkable Los Angeles homes of her time, remarkable both for their lavishness and their residents. Bobbe was also an outdoors woman and athlete, fishing and riding horses. She skied and played tennis competitively, often against men. She raised and trained dogs and was a sports car enthusiast, well-known for the rainbow-painted Porsche in which she made her real estate rounds. Bobbe traveled widely throughout Europe, Asia, Africa and the Americas. As a patron of the arts she greatly enjoyed classical music and in recent years, Lady Gaga. Her rapier wit and playful sense of humor was matched by her care and concern for others. Never one to talk about herself, Bobbe focused her incandescent personality on whomever she was with; her joyful presence absorbed as much as her quiet smile radiated. Bobbe leaves behind friends and classmates from Beverly Hills High School (1935, Class President), UC Berkeley and UCLA (1939, BA European History). She will be dearly missed by her family, including her niece Jeanne Meyers (Richard Carr) and nephews Charles Franklin (Susie) and Wayne Franklin (Susan); her grandnieces and nephews, Elissa (Clark Middleton) and Lucas Meyers (Margaret); Zachary Franklin (Sofia Zander), Seth Franklin (Kristin), Judd Franklin (Tybe Goldberg); and Jason Franklin, Barrett Franklin (Lea) and Shannon Hegarty (Terry); as well as by her great grandnieces and nephew, Ellington and August Meyers; Molly Franklin and Clara Zander; and Adena Franklin. Bobbe was predeceased by her younger brothers Benny (Ben Jr.) (same day as Bobbe, February 28, but 1973) and Maynard Franklin (2011). Beneficiaries of Babette's profoundly philanthropic nature include several health and educational institutes. She and her brother Maynard left the gem and mineral collection originally amassed by their parents, Ben and Clara, in Bisbee, to the Los Angeles County Museum of Natural History, where it can now be seen by all. 1

headline.main: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRANKENBERG, BABETTE MEYERS KNOWN TO HER FAMILY AND MANY FRIENDS AS "BOBBE," DIED FEBRUARY 28 AT AGE 98, HAVING LIVED A RICHLY VARIEGATED AND ADVENTUROUS LIFE THAT CHANNELED HER PIONEERING SPIRIT AS A FEMINIST BEFORE HER TIME. BOBBE WAS BORN ON MAY 16, 1916, IN THE HARDSCRABBLE MINING TOWN OF BISBEE, AZ, AND MOVED WITH HER PARENTS TO BEVERLY HILLS WHEN SUNSET BOULEVARD HAD YET TO BE FULLY PAVED. SHE WAS A SUCCESSFUL BUSINESS WOMAN IN THE 1940S, WHEN FEMALE ENTREPRENEURS WERE A RARE BREED, AND THROUGH THE 1980S, AS WOMEN INCREASINGLY ROSE TO PROMINENCE IN CORPORATE AMERICA. SHE FOUND GREAT SUCCESS IN COMMERCIAL AND RESIDENTIAL REAL ESTATE AS WELL IN PUBLIC RELATIONS. IN THE 1950S SHE HANDLED MARK TAPER'S PR FOR HIS AMBITIOUS LAKEWOOD DEVELOPMENT. WITH COLDWELL BANKER, BOBBE SOLD MANY OF THE MORE REMARKABLE LOS ANGELES HOMES OF HER TIME, REMARKABLE BOTH FOR THEIR LAVISHNESS AND THEIR RESIDENTS. BOBBE WAS ALSO AN OUTDOORS WOMAN AND ATHLETE, FISHING AND RIDING HORSES. SHE SKIED AND PLAYED TENNIS COMPETITIVELY, OFTEN AGAINST MEN. SHE RAISED AND TRAINED DOGS AND WAS A SPORTS CAR ENTHUSIAST, WELL, KNOWN FOR THE RAINBOW, PAINTED PORSCHE IN WHICH SHE MADE HER REAL ESTATE ROUNDS. BOBBE TRAVELED WIDELY THROUGHOUT EUROPE, ASIA, AFRICA AND THE AMERICAS. AS A PATRON OF THE ARTS SHE GREATLY ENJOYED CLASSICAL MUSIC AND IN RECENT YEARS, LADY GAGA. HER RAPIER WIT AND PLAYFUL SENSE OF HUMOR WAS MATCHED BY HER CARE AND CONCERN FOR OTHERS. NEVER ONE TO TALK ABOUT HERSELF, BOBBE FOCUSED HER INCANDESCENT PERSONALITY ON WHOMEVER SHE WAS WITH; HER JOYFUL PRESENCE ABSORBED AS MUCH AS HER QUIET SMILE RADIATED. BOBBE LEAVES BEHIND FRIENDS AND CLASSMATES FROM BEVERLY HILLS HIGH SCHOOL (1935, CLASS PRESIDENT), UC BERKELEY AND UCLA (1939, BA EUROPEAN HISTORY). SHE WILL BE DEARLY MISSED BY HER FAMILY, INCLUDING HER NIECE JEANNE MEYERS (RICHARD CARR) AND NEPHEWS CHARLES FRANKLIN (SUSIE) AND WAYNE FRANKLIN (SUSAN); HER GRANDNIECES AND NEPHEWS, ELISSA (CLARK MIDDLETON) AND LUCAS MEYERS (MARGARET); ZACHARY FRANKLIN (SOFIA ZANDER), SETH FRANKLIN (KRISTIN), JUDD FRANKLIN (TYBE GOLDBERG); AND JASON FRANKLIN, BARRETT FRANKLIN (LEA) AND SHANNON HEGARTY (TERRY); AS WELL AS BY HER GREAT GRANDNIECES AND NEPHEW, ELLINGTON AND AUGUST MEYERS; MOLLY FRANKLIN AND CLARA ZANDER; AND ADENA FRANKLIN. BOBBE WAS PREDECEASED BY HER YOUNGER BROTHERS BENNY (BEN JR.) (SAME DAY AS BOBBE, FEBRUARY 28, BUT 1973) AND MAYNARD FRANKLIN (2011). BENEFICIARIES OF BABETTE'S PROFOUNDLY PHILANTHROPIC NATURE INCLUDE SEVERAL HEALTH AND EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTES. SHE AND HER BROTHER MAYNARD LEFT THE GEM AND MINERAL COLLECTION ORIGINALLY AMASSED BY THEIR PARENTS, BEN AND CLARA, IN BISBEE, TO THE LOS ANGELES COUNTY MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, WHERE IT CAN NOW BE SEEN BY ALL. 1

snippet: Lawrie Mifflin became a Senior Editor in 2007, having spent 25 years at The Times in a variety of reporting, editing and management roles.  She now works with other senior managers to guide the integration of print and Web journalists and newsroom...
lead_paragraph:
Lawrie Mifflin became a Senior Editor in 2007, having spent 25 years at The Times in a variety of reporting, editing and management roles. She now works with other senior managers to guide the integration of print and Web journalists and newsroom processes.

Until April of 2007, Ms. Mifflin was the Executive Director of Television and Video for The Times, supervising all projects that involve The Times in television and Web video. The department produces original video journalism for nytimes.com, the leading newspaper Web site and one of the most popular news and information Web sites in the world.

She also supervised the production of television documentaries involving The Times, including several that won top broadcast journalism awards. After the launch of the Discovery Times Channel in March, 2003, her responsibilities included overseeing all content for that digital cable network, a joint venture of Discovery Communications, Inc., and The New York Times. That joint venture ended in April, 2006.

Read More...

From March 1995 until moving into The Times¹s television enterprises division in 1999, Ms. Mifflin covered television and other media news as a reporter for The Times. Previously, she created the Company¹s work-life services office, in the human resources department, serving as its director from March 1993 until March 1995. Before that, she served as an editor on the national desk and national education editor from 1990 to 1993, and as deputy sports editor from 1984 to 1990. She began her career at the paper as a sports reporter in 1982.

Before joining The Times, Ms. Mifflin worked for a year as an associate producer at ABC Sports, and from 1974 to 1981 was a reporter for The New York Daily News. She was that paper¹s first female sportswriter.

Born in Philadelphia in 1951, Ms. Mifflin was a member of the first class of undergraduate women to be accepted by Yale University. She graduated in 1973, with a degree in history. While there, she and a classmate organized the field hockey team, which in 1972 became one of Yale¹s first three varsity sports for women. She went on to receive a master¹s degree in journalism from the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism in 1974.

Ms. Mifflin was one of the first female sportswriters to work on a major metropolitan newspaper. After two years as a city desk reporter for The News, she became a sportswriter there in 1976. She has covered the major sports, as well as three Summer Olympics, the Lake Placid Winter Olympics, and, as a soccer specialist, two World Cup tournaments.

In 2002, the PBS Nova documentary "Bioterror," on which she served as co-executive producer, won an Emmy Award, The Times¹s first news and documentary Emmy. She was also co-executive producer on two PBS Frontline documentaries that won the Alfred I DuPont-Columbia University silver baton: "A Dangerous Business" (2004), which also won a George Foster Peabody Award, the Goldsmith Investigative Reporting Prize and, in combination with the articles in The Times, the 2004 Pulitzer Prize for public service; and "The Secret History of the Credit Card" (2005), which also won an Emmy. Her department won a third duPont-Columbia silver baton in 2006, for "Nuclear Jihad," a documentary co-produced by The Times, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Discovery Times.

Hide

headline.main: Mifflin, Lawrie

snippet: An article about Title IX and the roster management policies that universities use to balance their compliance numbers brought passionate responses from readers as well as a number of questions. Join the conversation....
lead_paragraph: With 270 comments and counting, New York Times readers reacted to my article in Tuesday’s paper about roster management with passion, insight and numerous personal stories about how Title IX had affected their lives, whether good or bad. Many readers questioned why so much attention is paid to female athletes and argued that the fact that 57 percent of college students are now female is proof of discrimination against men by colleges and universities. Others asserted that Title IX overlooks the fact that men and women have different interests, and raised the question of whether fewer women want to play sports. Still others said the examples cited in the article showed that, 40 years after it was passed, Title IX needs to be rewritten.
abstract: An article about Title IX and the roster management policies that universities use to balance their compliance numbers brought passionate responses from readers as well as a number of questions. Join the conversation.

headline.main: Gender Games: Answering Questions About Roster Management and Title IX

snippet: To the Sports Editor:    As the author of a book on female college coaches, I was glad to read ''For Female Coaches, Gains and Concerns'' (March 13). I strongly agree that female coaches are important role models for female athletes. The 60 coache...
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor: As the author of a book on female college coaches, I was glad to read ''For Female Coaches, Gains and Concerns'' (March 13). I strongly agree that female coaches are important role models for female athletes. The 60 coaches I interviewed often described the influence they have on their athletes' lives. Many female coaches are concerned by the declining number of female coaches. They argue that just as men can be excellent coaches for women, women can effectively coach men and ought to receive employment opportunities in boys' and men's programs. SARA GOGOL Portland, Ore. The writer is author of ''Hard Fought Victories: Women Coaches Making a Difference'' (Wish Publishing, 2002).
abstract: Letter to Editor addresses issue of female coaching opportunities for women's and men's programs (S)

headline.main: Role Models
